reviewText: In the 80's, after Friday The 13th copied the masterful execution of Halloween, thinned out the plot, characters, and actually put the violence on full display, the slasher genre was fully in place. Out of that came 100's of anywhere from decent to terrible slasher movies all copying the same concept: a killer in a mask killing teenagers we dont care about in various "unique" ways usually but not always as an act of retribution or revenge for something in the past and most of the time set on a holiday. There were some decent slasher films...mostly in the early 80's when the boom started. The Prowler, The Burning, Prom Night, Terror Train, Silent Night Deadly Night, My Bloody Valentine, Curtains are all watchable and pretty fun albeit dated slashers. Then you have others that are pretty bad but still entertaining for that very reason, films like: Humongous, Madman, Sleepaway Camp, Happy Birthday To Me, April Fool's Day, He Knows You're Alone, Splatter University, House On Sorority Row, New Year's Evil, Mother's Day, Dorm That Dripped Blood, The Mutilator and then we get to the real bottom of the barrel stuff like Cutting Class, Return To Horror High and Don't Open Till Xmas.Then....there's Nailgun Massacre. This one takes the cake. It is truly the legendary grade Z king of slashers. Most of the highly known movies of the genre all had at least some kind of independent financing or some kind of at least semi wide distribution. This one though, doesn't even have that, its pretty clear its as cheap and independent as film making gets. Acting? Nah. A script? Barely. Decent kill scenes? Nope. That was the main reason this sub genre was so popular, to see the special effect and how the victim was going to get it. This killer sticks to the nail gun the whole movie, after a construction crew gang rape an innocent girl, a killing spree begins picking all these guys off (and sometimes who's ever around). The only good thing about this movie really is the killer him/herself. Dawning army fatigues and a motorcycle helmet, it's probably as basic as you can get, yet somehow there is something kinda scary about it. However whatever might've been scary about this killer pretty much gets sapped away because he is shown in broad daylight most of the time, no suspense or slow build ups here, sometimes even being revealed watching a character step into their domain before killing them. It's pretty laughable but in a good way. The other "interesting" thing is the killer talks. Apparently to make you guess that maybe it's not a male doing the killing (which is typical for the genre) they disguised the killer's voice, but not only that, he/she speaks in this over modulated robot voice, in fact it kinda reminds one of Zordon from the Power Rangers...the one liners the killer speaks are just jaw dropping, it's so awkward to hear this thing talk, memory fails to recall any popular slasher movie where the killer ever talks, in fact its the silence that's a common trope of the whole style. It's the one stand alone thing that adds the complete cheese factor to an otherwise unwatchable movie.When the killer isn't on screen you can probably guess the horrible "actors" will bore you to tears but the dialogue is so insanely bad it makes up for the whole thing. The only thing that really eats away the whole "so bad its good" concept here is the ending. Yes we can sit through lots of terrible dialogue and characters and badly done gore scenes but in most slashers films there's at least a good third act with the final girl and the killer, revealing who he/she is. Not here though. There's plenty of nude women in this movie by the way, it really makes you wonder how the director talked all these girls into this. At the end of the day, Nail Gun Massacre is a buried 80's gem, that's packed to the brim with incompetent film making but given the killer's completely off the wall presentation it's a must see for bad movie lovers everywhere.

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie since I was a youngin'. This movie is so bad it's good. The Killer is hilarious and the version I got came with an insert making fun of how bad this movie is. Only buy this and agree with my review if you enjoy Cheesy, over the top, exploitation horror films that try too hard to be good.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Geeeezzzzz....more cheese please!!!  The title does deliver!  There is no other method that the revengeful killer uses; it's murder by nail gun all through this film. To some of you slasher fans, that might get a little old.  The killer does shot at different areas of the body but that about raps it up.  Also, this is another one of those flicks where the killer always says a lot of corny puns while killing someone.  That right there is good for a laugh but depends on the viewers humor.  I'm sure you know as well as I, that you don't go into watching a flick like this with high hopes as far as scare value goes. haha.  If your like me, you go for laughable dialogue and outrages acts done by "actors/actresses" and for the number one reason  (drum roll please), gore!  The gore is, well, not really that gory.  It would of helped if the makers could of been a little more creative in the splatter department.  But all in all, not bad.  There are enough scenes that made me flinch.  Again, you wont be finding 'Psycho' movie material here folks. DUH..lol!  I give it 4 stars only because the kills should of been nastier for flick to have such an awesome title.  Glad to have it; its definitely a conversation piece.
summary: You'll have a nail of a time! hehe...

reviewText: If you collect cult movies you need to have this in your collection.The dialogue alone is worth the price! Recommended!

reviewText: I'm sure everyone is buying this film because it's about a girl that gets raped, but what none of the other reviews mention about this film is that the rape takes place in the opening of the film and shows absolutely nothing (even the director's cut shows nothing). Everyone keeps their clothes on, and all you see is some people gather around her, making a few cat calls at her, and that's it.Then the few sex scenes that do appear in the movie are all consensual sex scenes, but terribly done so all you see are breasts or behind shots. Camera views show nothing.I do like the B Movie feel to it with all of it's cheesyness, good for laughs with friends.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Nail Gun Massacre" is one of those unfortunately films with a title that's better than the film itself. I tend to like movies with 'Massacre' in the title - Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Slumber Party Massacre, Toolbox Massacre, etc. - but this one doesn't quite measure up. It's not that it doesn't have a memorable killer, or laughably cheesy lines, or gore and violence. No, it has all of those Instead it commits the worst sin possible in exploitation movies: it drags. At 85 minutes, it's a little on the long side for this sort of movie. Herschell Gordon Lewis films were usually barely above 72 minutes and they had reasonably good pacing. A thirteen minute difference may not seem like a lot, but when you think about it, that's three or four long, boring scenes of pointless dialogue.It's difficult to make a recommendation concerning this movie. It's 50% cool, but 50% tiresome as well. The killer is fun to watch, and even though the motorcycle helmet is always present, you can usually tell when there's a stunt double because the killer suddenly becomes a few inches taller and has straighter hips. That and the terrible vocodered voice are the primary sources of unintentional laughs, which any exploitation film fan knows is basically the whole point of these films. There's a decent amount of syrupy blood and a sizable body count.My main complain is that it drags in so many places, that it is sometimes boring to watch. The setting is mostly out in a wooded farm area, so it's not like we have different sets to add a little visual interest. When most every scene looks the same (trees and the occasional wooden tool shed or old farm house), it becomes harder and harder to watch.The other complain I have is that the film thinks that its twist on the killer's gender is some clever that it gives away the 'surprise' on the back of the box when it mentions that the killer may be a man OR a woman. I suppose it's not a big deal since the killer's diminutive stature and curvaceous midsection kind of give it away from the first sighting. That plus, the killers identity is painfully obvious right from the beginning. Now that I think about it, maybe this isn't a complaint at all, but rather another element fans of the genre will find amusing.Synapse Films always gives us nice DVDs with a good array of special features, and this is no exception. The film has been remastered and probably looks about as good as one could expect. Terry Lofton shot this on a shoestring budget with limited technical skill in the art of filming. I don't hold any technical deficiencies against him because, after all, many terrible directors have made many highly entertaining films. That brings us to the "NAILED" featurette with director Terry Lofton. He seems likable enough, although you can tell that he's hurt by the criticism his film gets. He says in his defense, he had limited time, a limited budget, and he did the best he could. You almost feel a little sorry for the guy, since this was obviously a labor of love. There are also a few outtakes, but they're nothing incredibly entertaining. Overall, the DVD itself is very nice.Exploitation fans will want to check this out, regardless of my warning, and they should. Any fan of 'massacre' movies should see this once. I'm not sure if you'll need to own the DVD, or if renting is sufficient. I would lean toward the latter, unless you're a collector.
summary: Campy fun, but also boring at times
Title: N/A
